channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Police identify Luigi Mangione, 26, as man being held in connection with fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson
item.description: Thompson, chief executive of the Minnesota-based insurance giant, was shot and killed on Wednesday morning outside a hotel in Midtown Manhattan where he was scheduled to attend an investor conference. Police said they believed the 50-year-old was targeted. The shooting sparked a manhunt that spread beyond New York after police found evidence the shooter left the city on a bus shortly after the killing.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Husband vents his road rage onto his spouse in the car
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Husband vents his road rage onto his spouse in the car

item.title: Daniel Penny is found not guilty after his chokehold killed Jordan Neely on a New York City subway last year
item.description: Penny became a celebrity for conservatives, who praised the Marine Corps veteran for intervening while Neely shouted at and threatened passengers in May 2023. Neely’s family has said he was suffering from mental health problems and needed help.

item.title: EPA bans two cancer-causing chemicals used in everyday products
item.description: The two chemicals — perc, an industrial solvent commonly used in dry cleaning, and TCE, a substance found in consumer and manufacturing products including degreasing agents — are known carcinogens. TCE is associated with numerous cancers including non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, leukemia, and kidney and liver cancer. The new rules underscore President Joe Biden’s efforts to enact key protections against harmful chemicals before leaving office.

item.title: A rooster with ‘wings of fire’ in today's On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Golden Globes: ‘Emilia Pérez,’ ‘Conclave’ and ‘The Brutalist’ lead with the most nominations. See our full list.
item.description: In TV, “The Bear,” “Only Murders in the Building” and “Shogun” had the most nods.

item.title: Assad’s downfall. Trump’s threat. Jay-Z lawsuit. Border deaths. Walkable cities. College football. Ruby slippers. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Juan Soto reaches 15-year, $765 million deal with the New York Mets
item.description: The 26-year-old slugger was among the most coveted free agents in baseball history, and the Mets won a bidding war that included the crosstown rival New York Yankees — Soto’s former team — and the Boston Red Sox. The move will help the Mets compete with the World Series champion Los Angeles Dodgers and other powerful clubs in the National League after a surprise run to the NLCS this past season.

item.title: Why so many Americans prefer sprawl to walkable neighborhoods
item.description: Building more 15-minute neighborhoods would cut pollution and conserve nature. But do Americans want to live in them? See how walkable your neighborhood is.

item.title: Milk chocolate or dark? The answer could affect your risk of diabetes.
item.description: A large new study found that people who regularly ate chocolate had a lower likelihood of developing Type 2 diabetes. But only dark chocolate was associated with a lower risk of developing the disease, not milk chocolate. Researchers are not sure why that is, but they had some ideas.

item.title: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad lands in Moscow, Russian state media says, as Syrians rejoice at home. Follow our live coverage.
item.description: His regime crumbled under the weight of the armed Islamist group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham this weekend. Influential neighbors called for a peaceful transition as Western leaders hailed Assad’s fall with caution and called for regional stability.

item.title: The College Football Playoff bracket is set. Here’s who made the cut for the inaugural 12-team field.
item.description:
The selection committee unveiled the teams that will play in the first expanded edition of the playoff, which will culminate in the national championship game Jan. 20 in Atlanta.
The playoff begins with four first-round games at campus sites Dec. 20 and 21.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Scam victims often feel ashamed, but this group helps them heal. Catch up on our ‘Scammed’ series.
item.description: A support group for fraud victims helped an 80-year-old woman after she lost her life savings to a sophisticated scammer. Read the final installment of personal finance columnist Michelle Singletary’s “Scammed” series and any of the other parts you may have missed.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Bashar al-Assad's regime falls in Syria as rebels in Damascus claim victory on state TV
item.description: The armed Islamist group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham said early Sunday it had entered Damascus, the capital. Syria’s prime minister, in a videotaped statement, vowed to “extend our hand” to the opposition. With Assad's whereabouts unknown, an anchor on state television said "Syria has regained its freedom."

item.title: Damascus residents report hearing gunfire as Syrian rebels claim to enter the capital
item.description: Rebels entered the Syrian capital in a crucial stage of a lightning advance launched by the armed Islamist group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham less than two weeks ago. They say they are looking for President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: Syrian rebels enter strategic city of Homs, threaten Damascus, as army withdraws. Follow our coverage.
item.description: The Syrian army was “repositioning itself to the outskirts” of Homs, pro-government Sham FM said Saturday, as the Islamist group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham announced its entry into the country’s third-largest city, 90 miles north of the capital. The rapid advance of HTS from the north, joined Saturday by rebels from the south, has posed the greatest threat yet to the 24-year rule of President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: 45 definitive hotel rules that every traveler should follow
item.description: Hotels are here to serve you, but best not to push it. If you want to be an upstanding guest and expert traveler, you still need to follow the main tenets of a hotel stay. These are the rules for tipping, parking, cleaning and much more.

item.title: Virginia Gov. Glenn Youngkin claimed Jordanians ‘crashed’ Quantico. Feds say it was an Amazon delivery.
item.description: The Republican governor has used the arrest of two undocumented men, who misunderstood directions to stop at a check-in station, to inflame fears over illegal immigration. Federal prosecutors — who initially charged the pair with misdemeanor trespassing, but later dropped those charges — say that, while the Jordanians were in the country illegally and are in the process of being deported, they did not crash the gate or intend to do any harm at Quantico.

item.title: Corrects link: All-cash buyers are still snapping up homes. See where they’re buying.
item.description: The share of home buyers paying all cash reached 33 percent through August this year — one of the highest rates since the years after the Great Recession. Search by Zip code to see where all-cash purchases are happening near you. A previous alert directed readers to the wrong story.

item.title: All-cash buyers are still snapping up homes. See where they’re buying.
item.description: The share of home buyers paying all cash reached 33 percent through August this year — one of the highest rates since the years after the Great Recession. Search by Zip code to see where all-cash purchases are happening near you.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol impeachment vote fails after martial law decision
item.description: The South Korean National Assembly voted on President Yoon Suk Yeol’s impeachment Saturday but failed to meet the minimum ballot threshold after a boycott by members of Yoon’s ruling People Power Party. The failed vote, watched by thousands of protesters outside, is likely to trigger further political disarray and growing demands for resignation.

item.title: Trump has tried to move federal jobs out of D.C. before. It didn’t go as planned.
item.description: As he returns to the White House, President-elect Donald Trump has said he will relocate federal workers. Here’s what happened the last time he tried to do that.

item.title: USDA mandates testing of nation’s milk supply for bird flu, expanding previous efforts to fight H5N1 outbreak infecting U.S. cows
item.description: The order requires dairy farmers and processors to share raw milk samples before pasteurization. The broader testing, which public health experts have been clamoring for, is slated to begin the week of Dec. 16, after nearly 60 people, mostly farmworkers, have been sickened with bird flu in the United States.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: My wife is fed up with my ‘clingy’ friend
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: My wife is fed up with my 'clingy' friend

item.title: Dangerous women, a divorce party and wedding bell blues: Seven writers describe their overactive group chats
item.description: Everyone has at least one overactive group chat.

item.title: U.S. Naval Academy may consider race in admissions, judge rules, saying a diverse officer corps is important to national security
item.description: Last year, the Supreme Court rejected race-conscious affirmative action in college admissions, but the case included a footnote carving out the potential use of race in admissions within the nation’s military academies.

item.title: Are those delivery texts a scam? Michelle Singletary is answering your questions on financial fraud now.
item.description: In her new seven-part series titled “Scammed,” personal finance columnist Michelle Singletary deconstructs how one woman lost her life savings to a government impersonation scam. But how do you spot potential fraudsters? Ask Michelle your questions now during our live chat.

item.title: Appeals court upholds nationwide TikTok ban that is set to take effect in January
item.description: The D.C. Court of Appeals has turned away a challenge to a fast-approaching nationwide ban of short-video app TikTok unless it divests from Chinese ownership by Jan. 19. The court said the law is constitutional.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Employers added 227,000 jobs in November, a solid gain reflecting improvement in the labor market
item.description: The November jobs report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics adds more evidence that the labor market is healthy enough to allow the Federal Reserve to keep a more gradual path to lowering interest rates later this month.

item.title: Potential Trump targets. New York manhunt. Syrian rebels. Bird flu. Global warming. College football. Notre Dame. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Elon Musk revealed as backer of mysterious group defending Trump’s abortion stance
item.description: Filings showed the billionaire put $20.5 million into a group called RBG PAC that told voters Donald Trump would protect abortion access and was criticized by the family of late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

item.title: Shooting of UnitedHealthcare CEO in New York City, home to vast network of surveillance cameras, has fueled a crowdsourced manhunt
item.description: The shooter seemingly vanished after being caught on video in one of the world’s most surveilled cities, offering an online community of wannabe detectives a tantalizing case.

item.title: Spies are secretly at war with Russian drones. But Moscow is fighting back — with lots of lousy weapons.
item.description: Faltering Russian drones point to modest successes in Western sanctions to block Moscow’s access to technology. Yet, aided by covert operatives, Russia’s weapons production is soaring.

item.title: Major 7.0-magnitude earthquake strikes off the Northern Californian coast, prompting tsunami warnings
item.description: Shaking was felt across the northern part of the state, but the greater concern was the possibility of a tsunami. Tsunami warnings are in effect from near Santa Cruz, California, northward to the central coast of Oregon southwest of Eugene. Residents in these areas are urged to immediately evacuate inland and upward from the coast.

item.title: A single mutation of the H5N1 bird flu among U.S. cows could make the virus adept at attaching to human cells, a new study reports
item.description: There have been no documented cases of one human passing avian influenza to another, and researchers stress that other barriers remain before a mutated virus could be transmitted in that way. But public health officials worry about the possibility of a more dangerous strain of avian influenza getting loose in the general population that can more easily infect humans.

item.title: Police release new, unmasked photos of person sought for questioning in UnitedHealthcare CEO’s fatal shooting
item.description: The images released Thursday show the person sought by the New York Police Department as it investigates the shooting of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson. The pictures were distributed hours after reports emerged that investigators found a possible message on bullet casings found at the scene possibly suggesting a potential motive for Wednesday’s killing.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: She feels ‘monstrously vain’ about her upcoming facelift
item.description: Carolyn Hax: She feels ‘monstrously vain’ about her upcoming facelift

item.title: A sudden retirement at this struggling tech company in today's On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Syrian rebels enter the city of Hama as army withdraws in latest setback for Assad’s regime
item.description: In a televised announcement, the Syrian army said it had withdrawn from Hama after rebels entered the city from several directions. Islamist insurgents launched a surprise offensive last week, first capturing Aleppo and then heading farther south.

item.title: Brian Thompson. Pete Hegseth. Transgender care. French crisis. Memphis police. Bitcoin. Ancient canines. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Memphis police engage in excessive force, discriminate against Black and disabled people, Justice Dept. says
item.description: In a scathing 73-page report, federal authorities said they had identified a pattern of unlawful conduct, including serious problems in the way officers handle traffic stops and deal with children, as well as deficiencies in training, policies and accountability for officers accused of misconduct. The report comes nearly two years after Memphis police officers on a specialized street crime unit brutally beat Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man, after a traffic stop, injuries that resulted in his death three days later.

item.title: Trump moves to have charges dismissed in Georgia 2020 election interference case, citing his presidential win
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump’s attorneys argued in a court filing Wednesday that the charges against him are unconstitutional now that he will be returning to the White House next month. Trump and his allies are being prosecuted as part of a sprawling election interference case that accuses them of criminally conspiring to try to overturn the 2020 election in Georgia.

item.title: No-confidence vote topples French government as Le Pen’s far-right party exercises unprecedented power, stoking economic anxiety
item.description: The backing of Marine Le Pen’s far-right National Rally lawmakers was key to the success of the motion, which makes this the shortest-serving administration in the modern French republic, stalls efforts to plug a gaping hole in public finances and plunges France into political chaos. Prolonged uncertainty in the euro zone’s second-largest economy could have ripple effects across the continent.

item.title: Trump picks former SEC commissioner Paul Atkins to lead agency again, signaling a shift on regulation of finance and cryptocurrency
item.description: Atkins currently advises financial services and crypto firms. He served on the Securities and Exchange Commission from 2002 to 2008.

item.title: Supreme Court’s conservatives seem wary of blocking Tennessee’s ban on certain medical treatments for trans minors
item.description: The justices appeared deeply divided along ideological lines in a historic case involving gender-transition care for trans minors, with key conservatives expressing concern about courts intervening in an evolving nationwide debate over such treatment. The case is the first in which the Supreme Court has considered gender-transition care for minors, which has been banned in about two dozen states.

item.title: Cash App founder’s killing drew speculation of a random act. It instead offers a look into the underbelly of San Francisco’s elite.
item.description: A San Francisco jury will now decide the fate of Nima Momeni, the tech consultant accused of killing Bob Lee in April 2023.
